projects.title: Distributed Rate Limiter
projects.shortDesc: Redis-powered rate limiting handling 1,000+ req/s with sub-10ms latency
projects.fullDesc: A production-grade distributed rate limiting system designed to handle high-throughput API traffic across multiple server instances. The system uses Redis for atomic operations and implements the sliding window algorithm to ensure accurate rate limiting even under heavy load.
highlights: Handles 1,000+ concurrent requests per second across multiple Node.js instances
Achieves sub-10ms p99 latency using Redis atomic operations (MULTI/EXEC)
Implements 3-tier API authentication with different rate limits per tier
Sliding window algorithm prevents burst traffic from bypassing limits
Includes comprehensive monitoring with Prometheus metrics
99.9% uptime with automatic failover and graceful degradation

# Data pipeline for economic indicators
def process_economic_data(source, indicators):
    raw_data = fetch_from_source(source)
    
    cleaned = (
        raw_data
        .pipe(validate_schema)
        .pipe(handle_missing_values)
        .pipe(normalize_currencies)
        .pipe(calculate_growth_rates)
    )
    
    for indicator in indicators:
        upsert_to_db(
            table='economic_indicators',
            data=cleaned[indicator],
            conflict_key=['country', 'date', 'indicator']
        )
    
    return generate_summary_stats(cleaned)

projects.codeSnippet:
# Response rate analysis by company attributes
def analyze_response_rates(applications_df):
    response_rates = (
        applications_df
        .groupby(['company_size', 'industry'])
        .agg(
            total=('id', 'count'),
            responses=('responded', 'sum'),
            interviews=('interview', 'sum')
        )
        .assign(
            response_rate=lambda x: x.responses / x.total,
            interview_rate=lambda x: x.interviews / x.responses,
            ci_lower=lambda x: proportion_confint(x.responses, x.total)[0],
            ci_upper=lambda x: proportion_confint(x.responses, x.total)[1]
        )
    )
    
    return response_rates.sort_values('response_rate', ascending=False)
